options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: measure theory and some applications to calculus and functional analysis

The topics that we covered were essentially as much of the first 9 chapters of Rudin's Real and Complex Analysis. This includes starting from the basics of integrating with respect to a measure all the way up to Radon-Nikodym, complex measures, basics of Hilbert spaces, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Very clear instruction, was a fun class overall. The only weakness I could think of is that we had to sit through a proof of the Monotone Class Theorem.
Tom is a wonderful and kind professor! He is super understanding and helped make the course manageable, and I learned a lot from his lectures.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Being a math course, there's only so much room for "engagement". So I thought the course was completely fine in that regard.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes, if you're interested in higher levels of math. measure theory provides an important foundation in analysis. the material can be difficult and dry but Tom was a great instructor

I would recommend it to any student who's interested in analysis. If you've taken 305, this class might seem like an overlap given that you've done Lebesgue measure, but the two courses overlap only near the beginning of the course. Besides the theory of integration is done over abstract measures spaces, and the Lebesgue measure is simply a special case - so I'd think it's worth seeing again. There's also no harm to reinforcing your knowledge either.
